                                                                                                                                 A     third of the empire is forest-land.                       The oak forests on the Transylvanian
                                                                                                                           Alps abound in magnificent                 trees.
                                                                                                                                 The mineral             productions       of Austria are most abundant,                         Gold, silver,
                                                                                                                           quicksilver,    tin, zinc, copper, lead, iron, coal, are produced                           in large quantities.
                                                                                                                           The empire abounds also in precious stones, such as ruby, topaz, amethyst,
                                                                                                                           and especially the Hungarian opal, which takes a high rank in the market.
                                                                                                                           An immense quantity of salt is produced from the different mines of rock-
                                                                                                                           salt, or by evaporating                sea- water.         There are         1600     mineral       springs    in    the
                                                                                                                          country,      some of           them, such       as       Karlsbad         and     Marienbad,        being     popular
                                                                                                                          health-resorts.
                                                                                                                                 The agricultural               productions         are grain, rice, flax, hemp, tobacco,                  hops,
                                                                                                                          potatoes,      and       cider.       Hungary        is    rather       old-fashioned       in its    farming,        and
                                                                                                                          therefore as much is not made out of the land as possible, but the country
                                                                                                                          makes up for its deficiency in this respect by producing                                   an enormous quantity

                                                                                                                              The exports are silk and wool, Bohemian glass, and articles of luxury

                                                                                                                              The Turks are thorough Orientals. They wear turbans and long robes.
                                                                                                                          They will sit at their shops without moving from morning until night, doing
                                                                                                                          nothing but smoke.        They are very temperate : by their religion they are not
                                                                                                                          allowed      to take wine, and during the month of Ramazam they have to keep
                                                                                                                          a   strict fast.       How would you like                            it,   Jack   ?    Until sunset they may taste
                                                                                                                          nothing, not so much                  as       a    drop of water to cool their thirst                       ;   they may not
                                                                                                                          smoke    ;   and     this       goes       on       for    a month.         I      remember          reading       an       amusing
                                                                                                                          account of this fast being observed on board            or Nile boat. Though   a   deJiabcah,

                                                                                                                                                                           RUSSIA.
                                                                                                                                                                  U S S    IA       is     the largest              country     in   Europe,
                                                                                                                                                                      covering           an     area amounting                to more         than
                                                                                                                                                                      half the whole Continent.
                                                                                                                                                                             It     is    2   200    miles      long,    and 2000 miles

                                                                                                                                                                 A RUSSIAN VILLAGE.
                                                                                                                               The population of European Russia is about 74,000,000, but if we add
Public Domain in the United States, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-us-google
                                                                                                                          the territory in Asia, we should get an area of 8,340,000 square miles, with a
                                                                                                                          population of 86,000,000 ; so you can see what a mighty empire this is.
                                                                                                                                The army      is 788,000 in times        of    peace,   and 1,672,000     in war.   The navy
                                                                                                                          consists    of 269 steam-vessels, of which             29 are ironclads.
                                                                                                                                The naval ports       are   Cronstadt,        Sevastopol,    Nicolaicv.

                                                                                                                                                                          Russia.                                                275
                                                                                                                                The commercial         ports    are Odessa,
                                                                                                                                                                   Riga, St. Petersburg, and Archangel.
                                                                                                                          This latter is closed in by the ice for nine months of the year.
                                                                                                                                The     mineral      productions         are iron,      lead,   sulphur,   copper.        Gold and
                                                                                                                          platinum     are found       amongst     the     Ural Mountains.             Salt is found        in large
                                                                                                                          quantities    on the steppes.
                                                                                                                                Enormous forests cover a great part of the country.                            Pines    and Scotch
                                                                                                                          firs are, perhaps, the most common trees.
                                                                                                                                On the steppes there are large numbers of wild horses, sheep, and cattle.
                                                                                                                                The agriculture of the country is very imperfect, only a small portion
                                                                                                                          of the land being cultivated.                   Corn,    flax,    tobacco,     and   hemp      are chiefly
                                                                                                                          produced.
                                                                                                                                The     chief     industries     are     weaving        flax and hemp,         spinning silk and
                                                                                                                          cotton, tanning,       cutlery, and pottery.
                                                                                                                                The    exports    are timber,    potash, corn, flax, hemp.
                                                                                                                                The imports        are sugar,     tea,    coffee, cotton,        iron, wine, fruit,      machinery,
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-09-13 06:15 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433082470984
                                                                                                                          cotton, and silk stuffs.
                                                                                                                               The     religion of Russia         is   the Greek Church, of which the Emperor is
                                                                                                                          the absolute head.
                                                                                                                               The communications              in the interior are by good roads, numerous canals,
                                                                                                                          and about      11,000     miles   of railroad.          The Crimean       war taught         the Russians
                                                                                                                          the value of railways.
                                                                                                                                Now let me tell you something                 about        the people.     The great majority
                                                                                                                          of them belong to the Greek Church, and although, of course, there is much
                                                                                                                          in their form of religion that we should not altogether like, yet we cannot
                                                                                                                          help being struck with their intense earnestness.       The Russian never does
                                                                                                                          anything without recognizing God.       If he takes but a cup of water, he first
                                                                                                                          of all crosses himself, and offers a prayer to his Maker.  Every house in which
                                                                                                                          he   lives   must      be blessed     by the priest       ;   if he moves from one lodging to
                                                                                                                          another, his new lodging must be purifiedby a religious service. Twelve times
                                                                                                                          a year the parish priest goes round his district into every house, sprinkling
                                                                                                                          the rooms with holy water, and signing them with the sign of the cross.     In
Public Domain in the United States, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-us-google
                                                                                                                          every Russian home there are sacred pictures, with lights burning before them.
                                                                                                                          When the owner of the house enters, he stands on the threshold with reverence,
                                                                                                                          crosses himself,and utters a prayer.  Each one has his guardian angel, and
                                                                                                                          has a picture of that angel in his bedroom.   The day of his angel is kept
                                                                                                                          as a sacred      feast, on which        all the family are gathered              together,      and    alms
                                                                                                                          are given     to the poor.        The fasts the Russians keep are very                       severe.   For

                                                                                                                          276                  The Children s           Fairy            Geography.
                                                                                                                          seven weeks before Easter, for six weeks before St. Peter's                    Day, and for six
                                                                                                                          weeks before Christmas         Day, no flesh, fish, eggs, milk, or butter can be touched.
                                                                                                                          The Greek      service   is a very peculiar        service.      The chanting of the priests,
                                                                                                                          with their rich, deep bass voices, such as you hear in no other country, is
                                                                                                                          very striking.   No organ is permitted in their churches.  Besides Roman
                                                                                                                          Catholics,    Lutherans, and      Mahommedans,          there        are many peculiar sects   of

                                                                                                                               The people of Sweden are quiet, and industrious in their habits.     The
                                                                                                                          peasantry live in wooden houses, and have a strange dislike to having trees near
                                                                                                                          their dwelling, as they say they like to look out upon their beautiful                 country.
                                                                                                                          Their food     is salt meat, fresh meat being much disliked. Porridge and small-beer
                                                                                                                          are their favourite diet, and they usually have capital coffee.     Tea is very rare,
                                                                                                                          and then it is tea-watten, or tea-water, as it is called — about a spoonful of tea to
                                                                                                                          a gallon   of water — so that their nerves do not run much danger of being
                                                                                                                          disturbed.   The people are too fond of drinking the finkel, or potato-brandy,
                                                                                                                          which is the curse of the country.    By way of getting an appetite for a meal,
                                                                                                                          it is usual, as a preliminary, to have a piece of bread and butter, and to wash
                                                                                                                          this down with a glass of brandy.               They have curious customs at weddings
                                                                                                                          and    baptisms,    and    also   at Christmas     and Epiphany. They belong to the
                                                                                                                          Lutheran Church, and have             an   Archbishop, whose     see is   Upsala, and eleven
                                                                                                                          bishops.      The only active exercise they         seem   to care for is dancing,    of which
                                                                                                                          they are passionately        fond.
